overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students compare the percent relationships in markups and markdowns, tips, discounts, commissions, fees, and taxes. They identify sales tax rates from a table, a graph, and an equation and represent a percent situation using these representations. They make sense of the formula <math><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mtext>list price</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mtext> tax rate</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> to calculate the total amount paid in percent situations.

overview_item_data_items: I can use proportional reasoning to calculate sales tax amounts.
I can solve sales tax problems by determining the tax amount, the percent, or the amount taxes.
I can use proportionality to solve multistep ratio and percent problems involving taxes and fees by writing equations.

When calculating the total cost of a good or service that includes sales tax, <math><mi>x</mi><mi>%</mi></math>, multiplying the list price by <math><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mi>%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is the same as adding the sales tax, <math><mi>x</mi><mi>%</mi></math>, to the list price.
The relationship between an order amount and the total amount, including a percent fee, is proportional and represented by the equation <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi></math>.
Markups, tips, commissions, fees, and taxes represent increases over an original amount.
Discounts and markdowns represent decreases from an original amount.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students determine patterns in a number string involving percents.
Students learn about state sales tax, identifying it as a rate from an equation, a table, or a graph.
Students compare percent relationships in markups, markdowns, tips, discounts, fees, and taxes.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
